qas.question: According to a school of Vedanta, what is all reality?
What concepts of metaphysics are included in Vedanta?
How is the reality of maya viewed in Vedanta?
To what does the concept of atman refer?
To what do Advaita Vedantins view atman as the same?
Which metaphysic concept is never changing?
What is not within human beings?
What is the opposite of Brahman?
What do non-Advaita Vedantins say about atman and Brahman?
What is unchanging and what it appears to be?

context: According to this school of Vedanta, all reality is <a0_0>Brahman<a0_0/>, and there exists nothing whatsoever which is not Brahman. Its metaphysics includes the concept of <a1_0>māyā and ātman<a1_0/>. <b5_0>Māyā<b5_0/> connotes "that which exists, but is constantly changing and thus is spiritually unreal". <b9_0>The empirical reality<b9_0/> is considered as <a2_0>always changing<a2_0/> and therefore "transitory, incomplete, misleading and not what it appears to be". The concept of ātman is of <a3_0>soul<a3_0/>, self within each person, each living being. Advaita Vedantins assert that <b8_0>ātman is same as <a4_0>Brahman<b8_0/><a4_0/>, and this <b6_0>Brahman<b6_0/> is within each human being and all life, all living beings are spiritually interconnected, and there is oneness in all of existence. They hold that dualities and misunderstanding of māyā as the spiritual reality that matters is caused by ignorance, and are the cause of sorrow, suffering. <b7_0>Jīvanmukti<b7_0/> (liberation during life) can be achieved through Self-knowledge, the understanding that ātman within is same as ātman in another person and all of Brahman – the eternal, unchanging, entirety of cosmic principles and true reality.
